god damn python 2.7

elements.text: god damn python 2.7

messages.text: we all know its dead- like it's dead-dead. Yet, here it is again. Giving me flashbacks to tech. debt I had to contend with 3 years ago.

elements.text: we all know its dead- like it's dead-dead. Yet, here it is again. Giving me flashbacks to tech. debt I had to contend with 3 years ago.

messages.text: once upon a time I had a job. Where I was new. New-new. I wrote an API in python 3.something for some CV preprocessing. I went to merge it in with project repo. The project was done in python 2.something.

elements.text: once upon a time I had a job. Where I was new. New-new. I wrote an API in python 3.something for some CV preprocessing. I went to merge it in with project repo. The project was done in python 2.something.

messages.text: I was upset, and asked why - there was no answer.

elements.text: I was upset, and asked why - there was no answer.

messages.text: But we were doomed to using it

elements.text: But we were doomed to using it

messages.text: we depended on package releases from years come and gone.

elements.text: we depended on package releases from years come and gone.

elements.text: people pushed to master gigabytes of training data

messages.text: there was little hope left

elements.text: there was little hope left

messages.text: and then... a PM on another project recruited me. We were going to use Julia!? And that made my life much better.

messages.text: here's a thought for ya... Have you ever watched a movie and then realized a scene you remembered wasn't in it?

messages.text: but what about the other cases - you know what I mean?

messages.text: the mind has a tendancy to fill in the gaps for a lot of things.

elements.text: the mind has a tendancy to fill in the gaps for a lot of things.

messages.text: For example - humans in isolation tanks, negative decible audio chamber, or even extreme social isolation, tend to lose their minds.

messages.text: Alright look - there is no good programming language besides COBOL. They did it right.

messages.text: they made a lang to tackle a problem, and they did it so well it's been in use for 60 years.  Why? Because they satisfied their niche. Old iron is dreadfully dated - yet, if we pried open what many fortune 500 companies are running under the hood what would we all find?

messages.text: <@U01HLRSFPCN> has joined the channel

So for a while I believed I was running on Wayland and it turns out it was x11. What the... So Ubuntu 20.x ships with both! But they don't give you the gear icon in the GDM unless you specify it in a manually generated config file. Why. Why give users less options for the most bare screen imaginable in linux?

It's like a 32x32px button. Just include it. You already made us all download both as a redundancy.

elements.text:

It's like a 32x32px button. Just include it. You already made us all download both as a redundancy.

messages.text: this brings up the thought for the day. Simplistic verses Simple. It's really easy for developers to overlook the difference between the 2, but almost always when they do they inflict a bad UX on some poor population of users

elements.text: this brings up the thought for the day. Simplistic verses Simple. It's really easy for developers to overlook the difference between the 2, but almost always when they do they inflict a bad UX on some poor population of users

messages.text:
For example, someone might say "I want the UI to be as simple as possible". Well the simplistic solution is to just remove the option to choose between Xmonad, wayland or X11. But - it omits a very useful and simple option for making that change. Moreso it hides from the end user which one they are even using!

So this is a simplistic decision that results in making something that was already very simple, to failing to encapsulate it's purpose. IE: its a desktop manager, where else should one manage the desktop settings? Probably at the login - right?

elements.text:

messages.text:
This was once explained to me with GoLang. Go dev's decided "hey we don't want to support enumerations". Probably trying to save some effort.

Enums are arguably the most atomistic way to allow users to solve the magic number problem. Instead, they tried to factor out what an enumeration is by adding `iota` . What iota does is it will repetitively add +1 to its current value for each open param. at compile time. Filling in the numbers for you.

This sounds "simple" maybe even "simpler" but the reality is - it's a simplistic solution. We took an incredibly easy thing and made a foot gun. What if you have two iotas in the same file and one calls another? Guess what - it uses the same counter and now your faux enum is trash. Yikes. What if your values aren't +1 away from one another, say Port numbers, or error codes from some other software. Well you manually have to write them in.

So did it solve the problem? No. It was an attempted simplification of something that was already as simple as it could be and as a result, it failed to encapsulate the intended purpose of that which it tried to succeed from.

This sounds "simple" maybe even "simpler" but the reality is - it's a simplistic solution. We took an incredibly easy thing and made a foot gun. What if you have two iotas in the same file and one calls another? Guess what - it uses the same counter and now your faux enum is trash. Yikes. messages.text: <@U017J1FHTSA> has joined the channel
Alright it's been a few days since I updated the void with ramblings

elements.text: Alright it's been a few days since I updated the void with ramblings

messages.text:
I don't have a lot to say today really, except 2 things. 1 tech 1 nontech. Let's get the nontech out of the way.

So as I've been driving past small wooded areas lately my brain has been having instinctual thoughts to "set up camp". For the record, I don't like camping and it's cold as hell outside. So I think my brain is telling me to do something new. You know, break some cycles, blow out the cobwebs. Why that manifests as doing something stupid - I'll never know. Operating this meat machine has gotten tricky as years have gone by. Consciousness has a slow but sudden tendency to recede to penniless abstractions. What a mess...

messages.text:
that said...
I've recently realized the power of Rust-lang. Like yea its just a beautified C or something like that - but it's also not that. It solves too many of my problems. It's the first language to give me "blank canvas intimidation", too much potential to be productive that it has stifled my productivity.

The same thing happened when I got a 3-D printer. All of a sudden my barriers crumbled and I had no idea what to do with myself. Too much freedom can be a damning thing to creative people.

I am superpositioned in feelings of being on my way to creating my masterpiece, but I've also lost the majority of drive. Kinda sucks. Maybe that's a pathology for something - but that sounds irrelevent. Then again typing to yourself infront of an audience is also largely irrelevent. Anything in the name of science I guess.

messages.text:
I think one of the real reasons why the world sucks so much is, there are no supervillians. Like sure there are jerks, of all flavors, but there's no like evil masterminds out there like really trying to mess things up. Like as a child I thought I'd spend a lot of my life dealing with ways to stop maniacal geniuses from doing bad things - but alas, just garden variety not nice people, comiting random and/or opportunistic low-blows.

There's no like Dr Robotnik building some crazy space ship to do uncertain, but bad things to all the cute animals. Like you can't even appreciate the bad people of this world for what they do, you just have to cope with it ya know what I mean?

messages.text: I did meet someone in college, who, stated their life goal was to make a virus that turned people into zombies. I was like "woah that's awful" but at least it was interesting. I think they dropped out anyways... No motivation not enough back story. Not a compelling villian...

messages.text: I knew someone who worked in a forensic crime lab. I was like "that sounds like my calling explain!?". They were like "I basically blend up dead peoples brains/organs in a vitamix and do analysis to see how intoxicated they were when they die in car crashes". Then I felt sick and wanted nothing to do with it.

elements.text: I knew someone who worked in a forensic crime lab. I was like "that sounds like my calling explain!?". They were like "I basically blend up dead peoples brains/organs in a vitamix and do analysis to see how intoxicated they were when they die in car crashes". Then I felt sick and wanted nothing to do with it.

messages.text: guess what I'm saying is, if anyone knows a job that involves like mission impossible (the old school show not the new school tom cruise movies) or like forensic analysis of situations/chemical or otherwise where the outcome could actually help people not like "hey man this barrel of oil only had 10% aromatics , let me know.
